'''Wolfmother''' is an Australian [[hard rock]] band from Sydney. Formed in 2004, the group is centred around vocalist and guitarist [[Andrew Stockdale]], who is the only constant member of the line-up. The band has been through many personnel changes since their formation, with the current incarnation including drummer [[Hamish Rosser]] and bassist [[Brad Heald]], both of whom are former members of [[The Vines (band)|The Vines]]. The original – and most commercially successful – line-up included bassist and keyboardist [[Chris Ross (musician)|Chris Ross]] and drummer Myles Heskett. Ross and Heskett left Wolfmother after four years in 2008.

Stockdale, Ross and Heskett formed Wolfmother in 2004 after several years of informal jamming. Signing with independent label [[Modular Recordings]], the band released their [[Wolfmother (album)|self-titled debut album]] in Australia in 2005, which reached number 3 on the domestic albums chart. It was released internationally by [[Interscope Records|Interscope]] and [[Island Records]] the following year, and to date has sold in excess of 1.5 million copies worldwide. After Ross and Heskett departed, Stockdale rebuilt the band with the addition of bassist and keyboardist [[Ian Peres]], rhythm guitarist Aidan Nemeth and drummer Dave Atkins, who released ''[[Cosmic Egg]]'' in 2009.

In recent years, the line-up of Wolfmother has continued to change frequently, with their commercial popularity fluctuating. The band's planned third album ''[[Keep Moving (Andrew Stockdale album)|Keep Moving]]'' was released as Stockdale's solo debut in 2013, with a new line-up including drummer Vin Steele issuing ''[[New Crown]]'' independently the following year. In 2016, the group released ''[[Victorious (Wolfmother album)|Victorious]]'' as their first album on a major label since ''Cosmic Egg'', and subsequently toured with [[Alex Carapetis]] on drums. Wolfmother's personnel have continued to change, with Stockdale subsequently releasing and touring in promotion of his second solo album ''Slipstream'' in 2018.

==History==
===2004–08: Formation, early years and self-titled debut===
The genesis of Wolfmother began in 2000, when founding members [[Andrew Stockdale]], [[Chris Ross (musician)|Chris Ross]], and Myles Heskett started [[Jam session|jamming]] together, before officially |date=12 August 2014 |url-status=dead |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150619063611/http://www.musicreview.co.za/2014/08/12/interview-wolfmother-on-south-africa-independence-and-john-lennon/ |archive-date=19 June 2015 |access-date=6 November 2015}}</ref> Prior to this, Stockdale was a photographer, Ross worked in [[digital media]] and Heskett worked as a [[graphic design]]er.<ref name="wma"/> Ross came up with the name of the band.<ref name="soloBB">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/1559593/andrew-stockdale-kills-off-wolfmother-name-new-solo-album-out-soon-exclusive |title=Andrew Stockdale Kills Off Wolfmother Name, New Solo Album Out Soon: Exclusive |last=Brandle |first=Lars |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=25 April 2013 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> The first live performance of the newly christened Wolfmother took place on 14 April 2004 at Vic in the Park, a pub in Sydney.<ref name="musicreview"/><ref>{{cite news |url=http://articles.chicagotribune.com/2006-06-07/features/0606070037_1_band-jamming-rehearsal |title=A year of firsts for Wolfmother |last1=Raihala |first1=Ross |last2=Ridder |first2=Knight |work=[[Chicago Tribune]]|date=7 June 2006 |access-date=11 November 2015 }}</ref> The group were signed by Australian independent label [[Modular Recordings]] in August 2004, with whom they released their self-titled debut [[extended play]] (EP) ''[[Wolfmother (EP)|Wolfmother]]'' the following month.<ref name="allmusic">{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/artist/wolfmother-mn0000086250/biography |title=Wolfmother Biography & History |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |author-link=Stephen Thomas Erlewine |website=[[AllMusic]] |publisher=[[RhythmOne]] |access-date=6 November 2015 }}</ref> The EP reached number 35 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Australian Singles Chart]].<ref name="AUS">{{cite web |url=http://australian-charts.com/showinterpret.asp?interpret=Wolfmother |title=Discography Wolfmother |publisher=australian-charts.com |access-date=6 November 2015 }}</ref> The band toured in promotion of the release for approximately six months, during which time they signed an international recording deal with the [[Universal Music Group]].<ref name="wma"/><ref name="allmusic"/>

After producing a demo for Universal US imprint [[Interscope Records]] in Sydney,<ref name="2015pr">{{cite news |url=http://www.prnewswire.com/news-releases/wolfmother-deluxe-two-cd-and-two-lp-vinyl-versions-mark-10th-anniversary-of-bands-debut-album-slated-for-release-by-interscopeuniversal-music-enterprises-september-25-300115261.html |title=Wolfmother Deluxe Two-CD and Two-LP Vinyl Versions Mark 10th Anniversary Of Band's Debut Album, Slated for Release by Interscope/Universal Music Enterprises September 25 |publisher=[[PR Newswire]] |date=20 July 2015 |access-date=6 November 2015 }}</ref> Wolfmother began recording their full-length debut studio album in California with producer [[Dave Sardy]] in May 2005.<ref name="wma"/><ref name="allmusic"/> The band rehearsed for six weeks at [[Cherokee Studios]], before recording at [[Sound City Studios|Sound City]], Pass and [[Sunset Sound Recorders|Sunset Sound Studios]].<ref name="2015pr"/> Sardy took a minimalist approach to production, aiming to capture the "raw, emotive" nature of the band's live shows and prioritising "the perfect feeling" over a "faultless performance".<ref name="wma"/> Additional contributors to the record included Lenny Castro (percussion), Dan Higgins (flute) and Sardy himself (percussion).<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/wolfmother-mw0000756525/credits |title=Wolfmother – Wolfmother: Credits |website=[[AllMusic]] |publisher=[[RhythmOne]] |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref> "[[Mind's Eye (song)|Mind's Eye]]" was released as the first single from the upcoming album on 16 October 2005,<ref name="mindseye">{{cite news |url=http://thedwarf.com.au/news/7027/wolfmother-return-with-their-minds-eye |title=Wolfmother return with their 'Minds Eye' |author=Gene |publisher=The Dwarf |date=22 October 2005 |access-date=7 November 2015 }}</ref> which reached number 29 on the Australian Singles Chart.<ref name="AUS"/>

''Wolfmother'' was originally released in Australia by Modular on 31 October 2005<ref name="wmallmusic">{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/release/wolfmother-australian-version-mr0001598289 |title=Wolfmother (Australian Version) – Wolfmother |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |author-link=Stephen Thomas Erlewine |website=[[AllMusic]] |publisher=[[RhythmOne]] |access-date=6 November 2015 }}</ref> and reached number 3 on the [[ARIA Charts|ARIA Australian Albums Chart]], remaining on the chart for a total of 78 weeks.<ref name="AUS"/> By the end of 2007, it had been certified five times platinum by the [[Australian Recording Industry Association]] (ARIA), indicating domestic sales in excess of 350,000 units.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/httpwww.aria.com.aupagesARIACharts-Accreditations-2007Albums.htm |title=ARIA Charts – Accreditations – 2007 Albums |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] |access-date=6 November 2015 }}</ref> ''Wolfmother'' was recognised by radio station [[triple j]] with its inaugural [[J Award]], given to "an album of outstanding achievement as an Australian musical work of art – for its creativity, innovation, musicianship and contribution to Australian music."<ref>{{cite web|url = http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/jawards/05/default.htm|title = The J Award – 2005|website = [[triple j]] – The [[J Award]]|publisher = [[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]]|year = 2005|url-status = live|archive-url = https://web.archive.org/web/20090801170629/http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/jawards/05/default.htm|archive-date = 1 August 2009|access-date = 21 August 2019}}</ref> It went on to be nominated for the [[ARIA Award for Album of the Year]] in 2006 (and won the awards for [[ARIA Award for Breakthrough Artist – Album|Breakthrough Artist – Album]] and [[ARIA Award for Best Rock Album|Best Rock Album]]).<ref>{{cite web |title=Winners by Year: 2006 |year = 2006 |url=http://www.ariaawards.com.au/history/year/2006 |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]]|website=[[ARIA Awards]] |access-date=6 November 2015 }}</ref> Eight of the group's songs were included on the [[Triple J Hottest 100]] lists in 2004, 2005 and 2006.<ref>{{cite web 2015}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |title=Hottest 100 – 2005 |year=2005 |website=[[triple j]] |url=https://www.abc.net.au/triplej/hottest100_08/history/2005.htm |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting |publisher=[[Australian Broadcasting Corporation]] |access-date=6 November 2015}}</ref> In promotion of the album, the band toured throughout Australia in October and November 2005.<ref name="mindseye"/> They also performed at the [[Big Day Out]] festival in January and February 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.theage.com.au/entertainment/music/big-day-out-2006-20060106-ge1j2f.html |title=Big Day Out 2006 |last=Murfett |first=Andrew |work=[[The Age]] |date=6 January 2006 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref>

After its success in Australia, ''Wolfmother'' was later released internationally in early 2006 – on 24 April in the UK,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/release/wolfmother-uk-mr0001327611 |title=Wolfmother (UK) – Wolfmother |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |author-link=Stephen Thomas Erlewine on the [[UK Singles Chart]],<ref name="UK"/> and number 7 on the US ''Billboard'' [[Mainstream Rock (chart)|Mainstream Rock]] chart.<ref name="USmain">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/artist/wolfmother/chart-history/rtt/ |title=Mainstream Rock Songs: Wolfmother Chart History |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |access-date=7 November 2015 }}</ref> The song later won the [[Grammy Award for Best Hard Rock Performance]] at the [[49th Annual Grammy Awards]], the nomination for which Heskett had previously described as "an honour".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/wolfmother-honored-with-grammy-in-best-hard-rock-category/ |title=Wolfmother Honored With Grammy In 'Best Hard Rock' Category |work=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date=11 February 2007 |access-date=7 November 2015 }}</ref> The final single from the album, "[[Joker & the Thief]]", later reached the top ten in Australia.<ref name="AUS"/> The subsequent worldwide tour included appearances at festivals such as [[Fuji Rock Festival|Fuji Rock]] in Tokyo, Japan,<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.japantimes.co.jp/culture/2007/01/26/music/concert-previews/wolfmother/#.Vj2xHq7hCRs |title=Concert Previews: Wolfmother |last=Brasor |first=Philip |work=[[The Japan Times]] |date=26 January 2007 |access-date=7 November 2015 }}</ref> the inaugural [[Virgin Festival]],<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.mtv.com/news/1541661/chili-peppers-who-killers-help-virgin-fest-make-its-us-debut/ |title=Chili Peppers, Who, Killers Help Virgin Fest Make Its U.S. Debut |last=Montgomery |first=James |publisher=[[MTV]] |date=25 September 2006 |access-date=7 November 2015 }}</ref> and [[Reading and Leeds Festivals]] in the UK.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://www.musicomh.com/features/previews/carling-weekend-reading-and-leeds-2006 |title=Carling Weekend: Reading and Leeds Festivals 2006 |last=Woods |first=Tom |magazine=[[musicOMH]] |date=1 July 2006 |access-date=7 November 2015 }}</ref> On 14 November 2006, the band performed a [[cover version]] of "[[Communication Breakdown]]" by English hard rock band [[Led Zeppelin]] as a tribute to the band for their induction into the [[UK Music Hall of Fame]].<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.uncut.co.uk/news/wolfmother-in-led-zeppelin-tribute-tonight-65079 |title=Wolfmother in Led Zeppelin Tribute Tonight |work=[[Uncut (magazine)|Uncut]] |date=14 November 2006 |access-date=11 November 2015 }}</ref>

Stockdale, Ross and Heskett commenced work on the follow-up to ''Wolfmother'' in 2007, although Stockdale had previously revealed that he had been planning ideas for the band's second album as early as 2006.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nme.com/news/wolfmother/23954 |title=Wolfmother discuss second album |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |work=[[NME]] |date=17 August 2006 |access-date=11 November 2015 }}</ref> One of the new tracks revealed as in the works was "Love Attacker", which the frontman explained was about "people who use love as a weapon to manipulate and get their way through desire".<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nme.com/news/wolfmother/25685 |title=Wolfmother discuss new album |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |work=[[NME]] |date=8 January 2007 |access-date=11 November 2015 }}</ref> This song was later released as "Pleased to Meet You" on the [[Spider-Man 3 (soundtrack)|''Spider-Man 3'' soundtrack]] in March 2007.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/spider-man-3-music-from-and-inspired-by-mw0000581891 |title=Spider-Man 3 (Music from and Inspired By) – Danny Elfman: Overview |last=Erlewine |first=Stephen Thomas |author-link=Stephen Thomas Erlewine |website=[[AllMusic]] |publisher=[[RhythmOne]] |access-date=11 November 2015 }}</ref> Stockdale described the new material as "cinematic" and "epic", predicting that the resulting album would be released in early 2008.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.rollingstone.com/music/news/wolfmother-hard-at-work-on-cinematic-epic-new-album-20071119 |title=Wolfmother Hard at Work on "Cinematic, Epic" New Album |magazine=[[Rolling Stone]] |date=19 November 2007 |access-date=11 November 2015 }}</ref> In September 2007 the band released ''[[Please Experience Wolfmother Live]]'',<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.manchestereveningnews.co.uk/whats-on/film-and-tv/dvd-review-wolfmother---please-1003960 |title=DVD review: Wolfmother – Please Experience... Wolfmother Live (E) |work=[[Manchester Evening News]] |date=13 September 2007 |access-date=11 November 2015 }}</ref> which reached number 7 in Australia and was certified platinum by ARIA.<ref>{{cite journal |url=http://www.aria.com.au/issue923.pdf |archive-url=https://webarchive.nla.gov.au/awa/20071119130000/http://pandora.nla.gov.au/pan/23790/20071120-0000/issue923.pdf |url-status=dead |archive-date=2007-11-19 |title=The ARIA Report: Issue 923 |journal=The ARIA Report |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] |issue=923 |page=25 |date=12 November 2007 |access-date=11 November 2015 }}{{cbignore|bot=medic}}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.aria.com.au/pages/httpwww.aria.com.aupagesARIACharts-Accreditations-2007DVD.htm |title=ARIA Charts – Accreditations – 2007 DVD |publisher=[[Australian Recording Industry Association]] |date=31 December 2007 |access-date=11 November 2015 }}</ref>

===2008–11: Lineup change and return with ''Cosmic Egg''===
[[File:WolfmotherMTVAustralia2009.jpg|thumb|right|Wolfmother returned in 2009 after a brief hiatus with a line-up including [[Ian Peres]], Aidan Nemeth and Dave Atkins.]]
After their performance at [[Splendour in the Grass]] on 3 August 2008, it was reported that Wolfmother "looked tense and uncommunicative with each other", leading to rumours that the band were to imminently break up.<ref name="rumournme">{{cite news |url=https://www.nme.com/news/wolfmother/38693 |title=Wolfmother to split? |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |work=[[NME]] |date=6 August 2008 |access-date=10 November 2015 }}</ref> In response to the rumours, the band's manager John Watson revealed that he would be "releasing a statement about their status soon".<ref name="rumournme"/> Days later, it was confirmed that the group had split up – in a statement released by [[Universal Music Australia]], it was reported that Ross had left the band straight after the Splendour in the Grass performance due to "irreconcilable personal and musical differences", after which Heskett decided that he would rather leave than remain in the band without Ross.<ref name="splitnme">{{cite news |url=https://www.nme.com/news/wolfmother/38717 |title=Wolfmother split up |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |work=[[NME]] |date=7 August 2008 |access-date=10 November 2015 }}</ref> Ross and Heskett continued to work together on a number of musical projects, including [[The Slew]] and [[Good Heavens (band)|Good Heavens]].<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2010/07/interview-kid-koala/ |title=Interview: Kid Koala |last=Halle |first=Karina |magazine=[[Consequence of Sound]] |date=20 July 2010 |access-date=10 November 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/tv/interview-good-heavens-were-always-certain-about-what-were-doing/ |title=Interview: Good Heavens – "We're Always Certain About What We're Doing" |magazine=[[Music Feeds]] |access-date=10 November 2015 }}</ref>

Just a week after the departure of Ross and Heskett, Stockdale returned to recording the second Wolfmother album in Los Angeles, initially working briefly with [[The Raconteurs]] drummer [[Patrick Keeler]].<ref name="newsbeat">{{cite web |url=http://www.bbc.co.uk/newsbeat/article/10002367/wolfmother-weather-insane-period |title=Wolfmother weather 'insane' period |last=Cochrane |first=Greg |publisher=[[BBC]] |date=14 October 2009 |access-date=12 November 2015 }}</ref> After returning to Australia, he enlisted new members [[Ian Peres]] (bass, keyboards), Aidan Nemeth (rhythm guitar) and Dave Atkins (drums) for "Wolfmother Phase II".<ref name="newsbeat"/> The new members officially joined on 5 January 2009,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.youtube.com/watch?v=nA9mURqzYEo | archive-url=https://ghostarchive.org/varchive/youtube/20211117/nA9mURqzYEo| archive-date=2021-11-17 | url-status=live|title=Wolfmother Talks About Cosmic Egg, Band Member Changes |publisher=YouTube |date=31 July 2009 |access-date=10 November 2015 }}{{cbignore}}</ref> before performing their first live shows under the alias "White Feather" in February.<ref name="newsbeat"/> Recording for a new album commenced in March with producer [[Alan Moulder]], with Stockdale describing the material as "a little bit heavier".<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s2502024.htm |title=Wolfmother exclusive: Andrew Stockdale on old tensions and new album |publisher=[[Triple J]] |date=27 February 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090301135004/http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s2502024.htm |archive-date=1 March 2009 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref>

The first song released by the second line-up of Wolfmother was "[[Back Round]]", which was made available as a free digital download on the band's official website on 30 March 2009, after its debut live performance the previous week at the [[MTV Australia Awards 2009]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nme.com/news/wolfmother/43736 |title=Wolfmother return with new track, new line-up |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |work=[[NME]] |date=30 March 2009 |access-date=12 November 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/269085/wolfmother-back-around-with-free-download |title=Wolfmother 'Back Around' With Free Download |last=Brandle |first=Lars |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=31 March 2009 |access-date=12 November 2015 }}</ref> After the rest of the album was recorded, "[[New Moon Rising (song)|New Moon Rising]]" debuted on [[Triple J]] in August and was later released as the album's lead single.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s2654500.htm |title=Brand new Wolfmother single to premier on triple j today |publisher=[[Triple J]] |date=13 August 2009 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20090816094102/http://www.abc.net.au/triplej/musicnews/s2654500.htm |archive-date=16 August 2009 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nme.com/news/wolfmother/46617 |title=Wolfmother announce new album release date and tracklisting |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |work=[[NME]] |date=11 August 2009 |access-date=12 November 2015 }}</ref> The album, ''[[Cosmic Egg]]'', was released internationally by Modular in October. It was another commercial success, reaching number 3 in Australia,<ref name="AUS"/> number 16 in the US,<ref name="US200"/> and number 35 in the UK.<ref name="UK"/> ''Cosmic Egg'' was supported on the [[New Moon Rising World Tour]], which started in Australia and later visited North America and Europe.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://espanol.gibson.com/News-Lifestyle/Events/en-us/wolfmother-announce-tour-716.aspx |title=Wolfmother to Kick Off New Moon Rising Tour in September |publisher=[[Gibson Guitars]] |date=16 July 2009 |access-date=12 November 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.popmatters.com/post/112921-wolfmother-cosmic-egg-new-album-and-tour-dates/ |title=Wolfmother – Cosmic Egg (new album / |url=http://glasswerk.co.uk/magazine/article/6939/Wolfmother+European+Tour+2010/ |title=Wolfmother European Tour 2010 |work=Glasswerk Magazine |date=19 October 2009 |access-date=12 November 2015 |date=21 July 2010 |access-date=12 November 2015 }}</ref> The group also supported [[AC/DC]] on the [[Black Ice World Tour]] in Australia.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/wolfmother-to-support-ac-dc-in-australia/ |title=Wolfmother To Support AC/DC in Australia |work=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date=9 May 2009 |access-date=12 November 2015 }}</ref> The following year, the album was nominated in the [[Classic Rock Roll of Honour Awards|''Classic Rock'' Roll of Honour Awards]] for Album of the Year,<ref>{{cite news ===2011–13: Planned third album, Stockdale's solo debut===
Wolfmother began working on their third studio album in March 2011.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://wolfmother.com/news/208/ |title=In the Studio |publisher=Wolfmother |date=1 March 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20110521065749/http://wolfmother.com/news/208/ |archive-date=21 May 2011 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://fasterlouder.junkee.com/andrew-stockdale-calls-time-on-wolfmother/832952 |title=Andrew Stockdale calls time on Wolfmother |last=Mann |first=Tom |work=FasterLouder |date=19 April 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160222113607/http://fasterlouder.junkee.com/andrew-stockdale-calls-time-on-wolfmother/832952 |archive-date=22 February 2016 |url-status=dead |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref> In May and June they played a number of European shows, performing new material from the upcoming album for the first time.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nme.com/news/wolfmother/55523 |title=Wolfmother announce three UK shows – ticket details |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |work=[[NME]] |date=17 March 2011 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.gigwise.com/photos/63555/Wolfmother-Play-To-Fans-At-Liverpool-Academy |title=Wolfmother Play To Fans at Liverpool Academy |work=[[Gigwise]] |date=1 June 2011 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> Interviewed in June, Stockdale revealed that approximately "12 or 13 songs" had been completed and that he was self-producing the album, with engineering to be handled by Aidan Nemeth.<ref>{{cite interview |subject=Andrew Stockdale |interviewer=David Arkhult |title=Siesta! 2011 – Wolfmother Intervju |url=http://www.vimeo.com/24816624 |publisher=[[Vimeo]] |date=4 June 2011 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20121110023111/http://vimeo.com/24816624 |archive-date=10 November 2012 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref> The release date of the album was estimated as early 2012, with a number of shows taking place in Australia in promotion; new song titles leaked from set lists included "The Year of the Dragon", "Meridian" and "Everyday Drone/On the Beach".<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://musicfeeds.com.au/news/wolfmother-australian-tour-dates-2011-new-album-early-2012/ |title=Wolfmother Australian Tour Dates 2011 + New Album Early 2012 |last=Darke |first=Brayden |magazine=[[Music Feeds]] |date=14 November 2011 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> In October 2011, a [[cover version]] of the [[ZZ Top]] song "[[Cheap Sunglasses]]" was featured on the various artists tribute album ''[[ZZ Top: A Tribute from Friends]]''.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.blabbermouth.net/news/steven-tyler-mastodon-wolfmother-filter-featured-on-zz-top-tribute-album/ |title=Steven Tyler, Mastodon, Wolfmother, Filter Featured on ZZ Top Tribute Album |work=[[Blabbermouth.net]] |date=24 August 2011 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref>

After relatively few updates regarding the upcoming album, in February 2012 both Nemeth and Rockwell-Scott left Wolfmother.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://rockdirt.com/andrew-stockdale-wolfmother-lineup-changes-not-my-fault/36566/ |title=Andrew Stockdale: Wolfmother Lineup Changes "Not My Fault" |publisher=rockdirt.com |date=28 May 2012 |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref> Stockdale claimed at the time that the former had chosen to focus on engineering, while the latter was forced to leave due to health concerns.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.wolfmother.net/2012/02/24/wolfmother-in-turmoil-again/#comments |title=Wolfmother in Turmoil Again: Members Leave, Record Labels Run |last=Pusey |first=André |publisher=The Original Wolfmother Fan Site |date=24 February 2012 |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref> The following month, it was reported that former [[The Vines (band)|Vines]] drummer [[Hamish Rosser]] had joined the band.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.digitalspy.com/music/news/a371464/wolfmother-hire-axed-vines-drummer-hamish-rosser/ |title=Wolfmother hire axed Vines drummer Hamish Rosser |last=Davies |first=Rebecca |website=[[Digital Spy]] |date=16 March 2012 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> Around the same time, new rhythm guitarist Vin Steele replaced Nemeth, and keyboardist and percussionist Elliott Hammond was also added to the group.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://noisecreep.com/wolfmother-back-at-work-on-new-material/ |title=Wolfmother Back at Work on New Material |last=Srisavasdi |first=Greg |website=[[Noisecreep]] |date=15 August 2013 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> Both members' departures were compared in the media to those of original members Ross and Heskett, although Stockdale has denied accusations from some critics that he was to blame for former members leaving the group.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/upcoming_releases/wolfmother_stockdale_denies_tyrant_charge.html |title=Wolfmother: Stockdale Denies Tyrant Charge |publisher=[[Ultimate Guitar]] |date=25 May 2012 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> The new five-piece line-up continued recording material for the new album, which was delayed further for a 2013 release.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.ariacharts.com.au/news/35515/wolfmother-announce-brisbane-new-year's-eve-show |title=Wolfmother Announce Brisbane New Year's Eve Show |publisher=[[ARIA Charts]] |access-date=21 November 2015 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20150406093536/http://www.ariacharts.com.au/news/35515/wolfmother-announce-brisbane-new-year's-eve-show |archive-date=6 April 2015 |url-status=dead }}</ref> At the end of 2012, Stockdale announced that the album was "nearly complete", and that it would be titled ''Gatherings''.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/new-wolfmother-album-nearly-complete-says-stockdale/ |title=New Wolfmother Album 'Nearly Complete' Says Stockdale |last=O'Connor |first=David |publisher=Tone Deaf |date=18 December 2012 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref>

In March 2013, however, Stockdale announced that he would not be releasing the new album under the Wolfmother moniker.<ref name="soloFL">{{cite news |url=http://fasterlouder.junkee.com/wolfmothers-andrew-stockdale-goes-solo/832293 |title=Wolfmother's Andrew Stockdale goes solo |last=Levin |first=Darren |publisher=FasterLouder |date=6 March 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110083428/http://fasterlouder.junkee.com/wolfmothers-andrew-stockdale-goes-solo/832293 |archive-date=10 January 2016 |url-status=dead |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref> Describing the project as "a different trip now",<ref name="soloFL"/> he revealed to ''[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]'' magazine in April that the album would be released as his solo debut with the title ''[[Keep Moving (Andrew Stockdale album)|Keep Moving]]'' in June.<ref name="soloBB"/> "[[Long Way to Go (Andrew Stockdale song)|Long Way to Go]]" was released as the lead single from the album.<ref name="soloBB"/> Stockdale later elaborated on the decision to cease using the Wolfmother name; he noted that his desire to self-produce an album played a part in the change, adding the band had a "big producer" in line to work on their third album but he wanted to release the material he had already recorded, and so he decided to do so under his own name.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://fasterlouder.junkee.com/andrew-stockdale-why-im-ditching-wolfmother-and-starting-again/833583 |title=Andrew Stockdale: Why I'm ditching Wolfmother and starting again |last=Swan |first=David |publisher=FasterLouder |date=28 May 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20151210103858/http://fasterlouder.junkee.com/andrew-stockdale-why-im-ditching-wolfmother-and-starting-again/833583 |archive-date=10 December 2015 |url-status=dead |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> ''Keep Moving'' reached number 32 on the Australian Albums Chart.<ref>{{cite web |url=http://australian-charts.com/showitem.asp?interpret=Andrew+Stockdale&titel=Keep+Moving&cat=a |title=Andrew Stockdale – Keep Moving |publisher=australian-charts.com |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref>

===2013–17: Band's return with ''New Crown'' and ''Victorious''===
[[File:Wolfmother (7002459625).jpg|thumb|right|[[Andrew Stockdale]] briefly dropped the Wolfmother moniker in 2013, before returning to using it later in the year.]]
Just two months after Stockdale dropped the band's name, it was announced that Wolfmother were due to return.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://fasterlouder.junkee.com/stockdale-revives-wolfmother-two-months-after-split/848175 |title=Stockdale revives Wolfmother two months after "split" |last=Smith |first=Sarah |publisher=FasterLouder |date=12 July 2013 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20160110083428/http://fasterlouder.junkee.com/stockdale-revives-wolfmother-two-months-after-split/848175 |archive-date=10 January 2016 |url-status=dead |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref> The news was broken when Stockdale's solo shows were cancelled, shortly before a number of Wolfmother shows in the US were announced in their place.<ref>{{cite magazine |url=http://consequenceofsound.net/2013/07/wolfmother-reunite-10-weeks-after-breaking-up-announce-tour-dates/ |title=Wolfmother reunite 10 weeks after breaking up, announce tour dates |last=Roffman |first=Michael |magazine=[[Consequence of Sound]] |date=12 July 2013 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> In an interview with [[Triple M LocalWorks#Triple M|Triple M]] in 2014, Stockdale claimed that he did not intend to drop the Wolfmother name permanently, but instead that it had been temporarily "shelved" for ''Keep Moving''.<ref name="triplem">{{cite news |url=http://www.triplem.com.au/sydney/music/news/2014/4/higgo-and-rosies-interview-with-wolfmothers-andrew-stockdale/ |title=New Beginnings For Stockdale |publisher=[[Triple M LocalWorks#Triple M|Triple M]] |date=2 April 2014 |archive-url=https://web.archive.org/web/20140720203903/http://www.triplem.com.au/sydney/music/news/2014/4/higgo-and-rosies-interview-with-wolfmothers-andrew-stockdale/ |archive-date=20 July 2014 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref> Shortly after the band's return, Rosser left and Hammond moved over to drums; however, just a month later Hammond himself left as well, citing scheduling conflicts with his other band The Delta Riggs.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/reformed-wolfmother-hits-speedbump-as-members-walk-out/ |title=Reformed Wolfmother Hits Speedbump As Members Walk Out |last=Newstead |first=Al |publisher=Tone Deaf |date=24 July 2013 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> Hammond later claimed in 2019 that the announcement was in fact "a publicity angle to smooth it over".<ref name="sungenre">{{cite web |url=https://sungenre.com/interview/the-delta-riggs/ |title=Elliott Hammond talks Wolfmother and rock 'n' roll in the #MeToo era |last=Webb |first=Dan |publisher=Sungenre |date=19 January 2019 |access-date=19 January 2019 }}</ref> He was replaced briefly by Tony McCall, who left just a few weeks later due to "personal reasons".<ref>{{cite web |url=http://archive.alternativenation.net/wolfmother-drummer-quits-only-a-few-weeks-after-joining-band/ |title=Wolfmother Drummer Quits Only a Few Weeks After Joining Band |publisher=Alternative Nation |date=8 August 2013 |archive-url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:QETPoSOmCDQJ:archive.alternativenation.net/wolfmother-drummer-quits-only-a-few-weeks-after-joining-band/ |archive-date=6 December 2018 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref> Drummer [[Gregg Bissonette]] was briefly enlisted to record with the band, although his parts were ultimately not used.<ref name="trio">{{cite web |url=http://archive.alternativenation.net/wolfmother-change-lineup-again-guitarist-is-bands-8th-drummer/ |title=Wolfmother Change Lineup Again: Guitarist Is Band's 8th Drummer |publisher=Alternative Nation |date=8 November 2013 |archive-url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:ERInU4xIDm4J:archive.alternativenation.net/wolfmother-change-lineup-again-guitarist-is-bands-8th-drummer/+&cd=1&hl=en&ct=clnk&gl=uk |archive-date=8 December 2018 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref>

In November 2013, Wolfmother returned after a brief hiatus as a trio for the first time since 2008, with rhythm guitarist Vin Steele moving over to drums.<ref name="trio"/><ref name="trio2">{{cite news |url=https://tonedeaf.thebrag.com/reformed-wolfmother-playing-free-aussie-gig-working-on-new-album/ |title=Reformed Wolfmother Playing Free Aussie Gig, Working on New Album |last=Newstead |first=Al |publisher=Tone Deaf |date=7 November 2013 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> The new line-up's first performance took place at The Northern in [[Byron Bay, New South Wales|Byron Bay]], and it was hinted at the same time that the group would be working on new material for an album to be released in March or April 2014.<ref name="trio2"/> The album in question, ''[[New Crown]]'', was released without a prior announcement on 24 March 2014 as a digital download on [[Bandcamp]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.nme.com/news/wolfmother/76283 |title=Wolfmother release surprise new album 'New Crown' – listen |last=Bychawski |first=Adam |work=[[NME]] |date=24 March 2014 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/5944905/wolfmother-surprises-with-new-crown-album-release-listen |title=Wolfmother Surprises With 'New Crown' Album Release: Listen |last=Brandle |first=Lars |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]]  |date=25 March 2014 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> Self-produced by Stockdale, ''New Crown'' was also self-released by the band without a record label; speaking about the decision to do this, Stockdale complained that "it's a very long process getting anything done" with a label, noting that to avoid potential delays they took the decision to self-release the album.<ref name="triplem"/> Despite the lack of promotion, ''New Crown'' charted on the US ''Billboard'' 200 at number 160.<ref name="US200"/> The album was promoted on tour in North America during the months after its release.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.axs.com/wolfmother-performs-at-the-cosmopolitan-of-las-vegas-15329 |title=Wolfmother performs at the Cosmopolitan of Las Vegas |last=Emmer |first=Christa |publisher=[[AXS (ticket merchant)|AXS]] |date=28 July 2014 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref>

Wolfmother's self-titled debut album was re-released in September 2015 to coincide with its tenth anniversary. In addition to the original 13 tracks, the album contains five B-sides and 15 rare tracks, including 11 previously unreleased recordings.<ref name="wm10bb">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/news/6634751/wolfmother-debut-deluxe-10th-anniversary |title=Wolfmother Frontman Reflects on 10-Year Anniversary of Band's Debut Album |last=Baltin |first=Steve |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=20 July 2015 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref> In February 2016, the group's fourth album ''[[Victorious (Wolfmother album)|Victorious]]'' was released.<ref name="victoriousbb">{{cite magazine |url=https://www.billboard.com/articles/columns/rock/6769305/wolfmother-interview-victorious-andrew-stockdale-new-album-2016 |title=New Wolfmother! Band Shares Details of 2016 Album (Exclusive) |last=Baltin |first=Steve |magazine=[[Billboard (magazine)|Billboard]] |date=19 November 2015 |access-date=20 November 2015 }}</ref><ref name="victoriousbb"/> in addition to Ian Peres on keyboards.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.allmusic.com/album/victorious-mw0002905882 |title=Victorious – Wolfmother: Songs, Reviews, Credits |last=Jurek |first=Thom |website=[[AllMusic]] |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref> It reached number 17 on the Australian Albums Chart,<ref name="AUS"/> number 25 in the UK,<ref name="UK"/> and number 71 in the US.<ref name="US200"/> Lead single "[[Victorious (Wolfmother song)|Victorious]]" registered at number 26 on the ''Billboard'' Mainstream Rock chart.<ref name="USmain"/> Wolfmother promoted |title=Wolfmother's Andrew Stockdale Talks 'Victorious' Album, Reveals North American Tour Dates |last=Childers |first=Chad |magazine=Loudwire |date=20 November 2015 |access-date=21 November 2015 }}</ref><ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.loudersound.com/news/wolfmother-confirm-european-tour |title=Wolfmother Confirm European Tour |last=Lach |first=Stef |work=[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]] |date=18 January 2016 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref> which featured [[Alex Carapetis]] on drums.<ref>{{cite news |url=http://www.udiscovermusic.com/howlin-wolfmother-rock-icons-return-victorious |title=Howlin' Wolfmother: Rock Icons Return 'Victorious' |publisher=uDiscoverMusic |date=19 February 2016 |access-date=19 February 2016 }}</ref> In July 2016, the group supported [[Guns N' Roses]] at two US dates on the [[Not in This Lifetime... Tour]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.loudersound.com/news/wolfmother-to-support-guns-n-roses-in-pittsburgh-and-philadelphia |title=Wolfmother to support Guns N' Roses in Pittsburgh and Philadelphia |last=Lach |first=Stef |work=[[Classic Rock (magazine)|Classic Rock]] |date=3 July 2016 |access-date=7 March 2019 }}</ref> They later returned for shows in Australia and New Zealand in early 2017.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.axs.com/uk/guns-n-roses-recruit-wolfmother-as-opening-act-for-new-zealand-shows-i-111865 |title=Guns N Roses recruit Wolfmother as opening act for New Zealand shows in 2017 |last=Shackleford |first=Tom |publisher=[[AXS (ticket merchant)|AXS]] |date=19 December 2016 |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref>

=== 2017–present: Single releases, ''Slipstream'' and ''Rock'n'Roll Baby'' ===
Following the conclusion of the ''Victorious'' touring cycle, Hamish Rosser returned to Wolfmother.<ref>{{cite web |url=https://thespeakeasy.co.nz/2017/06/11/in-review-wolfmother-at-the-powerstation-962017/ |title=In Review: Wolfmother at the Powerstation 9/6/2017 |last=Moodie |first=Shawn |publisher=The Speakeasy |date=11 June 2017 |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref> In March 2017, Stockdale released a self-produced song called "Special Lady", which he recorded on a laptop using the program [[GarageBand]] and only a vocal microphone.<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.examiner.com.au/story/4604518/wolfmother-at-the-door-of-new-age/ |title=Wolfmother's Andrew Stockdale talks changes to the music industry ahead of Launceston show |last=Geale |first=Hamish |work=[[The Examiner (Tasmania)|The Examiner]] |date=19 April 2017 |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref> This was followed in November by the single "Freedom Is Mine", recorded and produced at Stockdale's home studio in [[Byron Bay, New South Wales|Byron Bay]],<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.therockpit.net/2017/wolfmother-release-brand-new-single-freedom-is-mine/ |title=Wolfmother release brand new single 'Freedom Is Mine' |publisher=The Rockpit |date=15 November 2017 |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref> and "Happy Wolfmothers Day" in May 2018.<ref name="slipstream">{{cite news |url=https://www.ultimate-guitar.com/news/community_feed/wolfmother_frontman_andrew_stockdale_releases_new_solo_album_wolfmother_tours_us.html |title=Wolfmother Frontman Andrew Stockdale releases new solo album. Wolfmother tours US |publisher=[[Ultimate Guitar]] |date=18 September 2018 |access-date=22 February 2019 }}</ref> Peres left in early 2018 after nine years with the band, committing to tour dates with [[Xavier Rudd]] instead.<ref name="slipstream"/> Stockdale and Rosser have performed with multiple touring line-ups of the group since Peres' departure: in April 2018 with Dave Atkins on rhythm guitar and Jake Bennett on bass,<ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.setlist.fm/setlist/wolfmother/2018/hamilton-hotel-brisbane-australia-5becfb34.html |title=Wolfmother Concert Setlist at Mojo Burning Festival 2018 on April 14, 2018 |publisher=Setlist.fm |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref><ref>{{cite web |url=https://www.facebook.com/wolfmother/videos/10156140777722667/ |title=Psyched to be playing The Mojo Burning Festival this Saturday... |publisher=Facebook |date=12 April 2018 |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref> from May with [[Brad Heald]] on bass and [[Lachy Doley]] on keyboards,<ref>{{cite web |url=http://www.marquee.theater/events/wolfmother-3639233/ |title=Wolfmother |publisher=[[Marquee Theatre]] |date=21 September 2018 |archive-url=http://webcache.googleusercontent.com/search?q=cache:GO8efMOnHFQJ:www.marquee.theater/events/wolfmother-3639233/ |archive-date=23 January 2019 |access-date=4 March 2019 }}</ref> and later in the year with Katie McGurl in place of Doley. Bobby Poulton began playing bass and keyboards in October 2018 and is now the current session player in the band.<ref name="slipstream"/> In September 2018, Stockdale released his second solo album, ''Slipstream'', which he promoted on a short concert tour.<ref name="slipstream"/>

In April 2019, Stockdale began recording material for a fifth Wolfmother album at [[Dave Grohl]]'s Studio 606 in [[Northridge, Los Angeles]].<ref>{{cite news |url=https://www.triplem.com.au/story/wolfmother-are-back-in-the-studio-and-dave-grohl-crashed-the-recording-session-134388 |title=Wolfmother Are Back in the Studio And Dave Grohl Crashed The Recording Session |last=Walker |first=Cassie |publisher=[[Triple M (radio network)|Triple M]] |date=11 April 2019 |access-date=27 April 2019 }}</ref> This album, titled ''Rock'n'Roll Baby'', wound up being released on 29 December 2019.

On 24 October 2020, Stockdale performed "Joker & the Thief" at the [[2020 AFL Grand Final]].
